text: [Music]
[Applause]
I'm Jeff bar team speaking with me near
Mirza general manager of Amazon upstream
welcome thanks Jeff what is upstream all
about
well Amazon app stream is a fully
managed streaming application service
it's meant to securely deliver desktop
applications from AWS to any desktop or
any device it is meant to address all
the issues with scale with security that
comes with deploying and managing large
applications to end-users within an
enterprise what problems did we set out
to solve when we built us there's three
sort of key things I think that we heard
from customers one supporting multiple
computers and operating systems people
found it very tricky to deploy
applications across a plethora of
different OSS and OS versions that
people had on their desktops and just a
variety of different desktops and
laptops that were supported out there
the second thing is actually securing
the applications and the data generated
and associated with those applications
customers were concerned with you know
the data at rest on their devices and
how it actually got back and forth
between their services and their
end-users and lastly it's just scale you
know in the typical AWS fashion you're
wanting to make sure that you have this
service that is centrally managed that
is pay-as-you-go you you pay for what
you use and you don't have to worry
about setting up and managing the
infrastructure the compute required to
deploy your applications okay so what
actual code resides on the user's
desktop when they're using an
application that's powered by upstream
well one of two things it could be that
Native Client it's a Windows 32 client
that is there today or it's just your
browser um and actually that's how
upstream got started was just you know
delivering these applications via the
browser and I think that that's exactly
what we wanted to go for and so far as a
value proposition that it would be very
easy to make your applications
ubiquitous so the either hit a URL with
the browser or they install the client
once and then and then that is it
they're up and running
yeah and then you access your
applications as if you're just invoking
them by double-tapping it like you would
otherwise why do our customers like this
they like it for a lot of different
reasons I and the enterprise what we're
seeing is it gives access to that
application that
part of your sort of line of business
what we found talking to a lot of
enterprise customers was that they're
saying hey look I have to buy this
expensive software and this expensive
hardware that goes on with it why do I
need to do both I need the software for
my employees to get their job done but
I'm paying for this hardware that's
sitting idle at their desk for the
majority of the day how can i balance
those costs much better in in the public
sector you have schools for instance
like edu that are setting up trials and
perm you setting up classrooms setting
up these virtual labs that you have
ongoing and then the last thing are
these software vendors or independent
software vendors Rhys visas we like to
call them they're doing a variety of
different things with them from demos
from training materials to trials and
and some of my favorite use cases that
I'm seeing is these ISPs are using the
app stream to enable the sassa fication
or software as a service of their
software for customers so effectively
giving them a new business model to
deliver totally new business model and
it's a it's a right once and deliver it
however many times as you would like I
also get the sensitive if I'm an admin I
don't want to worry about the variety of
different Windows desktops and patch
levels and versions that are out there
that's exactly that is exactly one of
the key problems that we wanted to
eliminate you know we just wanted to
make it easy for the surface to be
centrally managed you know which version
of the app the customer is using is
deployed if they call your helpdesk you
don't have to ask them like hey which
one did you install is the latest one
what's happening are you up-to-date with
the latest security patches etc that
stuff is stuff that we want to take you
know how does the admin go about
preparing an application to be used
within upstream yes so it starts by
creating an image and so first thing you
you create your sort of base operating
system image on top of that you layer on
the application within that image and
then you deliver that image to your
fleet
and that's basically the the you know
straightforward way that we've set up
for customers to get going with app
stream okay yeah what kind of feedback
are you getting from our customers lots
of really really positive feedback so
some of our customers for instance
multi-view it's a financial services
company that that uses it exactly in
that scenario that I described where you
know they've taken app stream as a way
to satisfy their software they would
otherwise have to rewrite for all these
different platforms this is the easiest
way to accomplish that for them and it's
allowed them to focus on their core
value which is being this financial
services software company we're also
seeing you know some trials and demos
that are being set up
MathWorks is a company that very
famously they have a piece of
mathematical software called MATLAB they
go through a bunch of higher education
places and they deliver these trainings
with app stream they've been able to
save 75 percent of the time required to
actually deliver these trainings and set
up for these trainings so fairly fairly
substantial insofar as you know making
it easier for them to get going with
with just doing the training and lastly
you know there's a company called core
expert with whom we've had a chance to
work with that they're cool because you
know they're both a partner that that's
working to get app stream out to
customers but also using it internally
themselves and and they have a very
famous you know ERP software sa P that
they deliver a GUI via app stream to
their end users as well so really really
exciting in a whole variety of different
ways that customers are engaging with
our services now it used to be the case
that the IT always had to give their
their user base the latest and greatest
pcs to make sure that they were capable
enough to run the latest and greatest OS
and software yeah does this mitigate
that that kind of forced upgrade model
well well as an end user I always hope
that my IT team is going to give me the
latest and greatest pcs but
realistically but it absolutely
decouples them there's no two ways about
it right like and it allows the IT team
to be very cost effective it allows a
user to have access to the latest
software that they need to be able to
get their job done and so yeah those two
things are decoupled and you can think
about that much
or simply as an IT person perfect yeah
any other things we need to discuss now
I know you know you can go to our
